job_title: Patient Care Technician/Float Pool in Cedar Rapids, IA
pros: Great people to work with, most of the people who work here are so friendly and actually seem to care about you
cons: Short staff!! You need to know you might have 30 patients to 1 tech!

job_title: Payment Posting Representative in Cedar Rapids, IA
pros: My particular job was amazing, I had very little contact with patients or anyone on the "outside". Our supervisors left us alone for the most part, due to our very strict, time sensitive demands we had, and we only answered the phone if necessary. It was a very quiet atmosphere and very routine each day, which was what I loved about the job.
cons: I was lowest hire, so I was laid off. Brought back 4 months after covid started and was told I was going to get laid off again after derecho hit. It was too stressful to deal with, so I found other employment. Broke my heart...

job_title: Senior Director in Cedar Rapids, IA
pros: Good culture, supportive team environment
cons: Staffing shortages cause stress for team members

job_title: Operations Supervisor in Cedar Rapids, IA
pros: Great Team to work with and good work/life balance
cons: Few growth opportunities without masters

job_title: Clinic RN in Cedar Rapids, IA
pros: Patient relationships are important for you
cons: Management uses unfair hiring, firing, favoritism

job_title: Certified Medical Assistant (CMA) in Cedar Rapids, IA
pros: I did have the luck of being hired at a facility that had some awesome physicians
cons: Individuals who were in a management position told you one thing but when held to what they said never followed through. Major favoritism was blatantly obvious.

review_title: I wish they would or could fine tune some things.
job_title: Certified Surgical Technologist (CST) in Cedar Rapids, IA
pros: Most of the team is GREAT, competitive-ish pay (if you luck into it). Tuition reimbursement / partial tuition paid.  In the end, employment will definitely depend on finding the right team for you.
cons: Mandated overtime on certain units, prior to covid, even. Administration more worried about their Heart building and “productivity” in budget versus having units that run cohesively. Physicians perpetuate the competition between Mercy and Luke’s - which makes already burnt out staff have to put in even more work so we don’t lose business. While there is truly great staff, there are still MANY “bodies” that would be terminated if there were more staffing options. Some units are required to stay for 24+ hours if no one arrives to replace them. HR not actually helpful in many of these situations, besides giving you the run of the mill, “we cannot answer about legality, but we can tell you this is our policy.” When asked about internal revenue adjustments, some staff were told they could, “quit, then come back in 6 months” if they would like an adjusted rate of pay - meanwhile some have received the increase in pay in a seemingly lackadaisical manner. I will say, I don’t think any of these complaints are any different with any other employer.

job_title: Central Scheduling in Cedar Rapids, IA
pros: Good people and PTO flexible
cons:
Low pay for what we do 
You have to pay for holidays

job_title: Education Specialist II in Cedar Rapids, IA
pros: Very caring coworkers and supportive management
cons: Low pay, poor health insurance

job_title: Patient Care Technician in Cedar Rapids, IA
pros: Great coworkers, generally good environment to work in.
cons: Healthcare has taken a 180 degree turn toward being insufferable to work in. Constantly on diversion, no open beds or staff to take care of patients, not enough supplies on the floors and generally feeling overwhelmed. It's not even Mercy who caused the issue, it's healthcare as we know it failing.

job_title: Licensed Practical Nurse (LPN) in Tyler, TX
pros: My manager and nursing staff were like a 2nd family to me. Even though Dr Boyles worked at a big family practice, he always had a small town doctor type of personality with his patients.
cons: Most weeks had 5 hour overtime.

review_title: Great place to work as a student
job_title: Patient Care Technician in Cedar Rapids, IA
pros: Great teamwork, most coworkers were willing to help and teach me as a tech. I gained so much experience this way.
cons: There were unsafe staffing ratios at times. As a tech, I often felt underappreciated by management. The nursing staff was very appreciative though.

job_title: Patient Registrar in Cedar Rapids, IA
pros: the pay raise and the diversity of people.

job_title: Nurse in Cedar Rapids, IA

review_title: Cares about me as an employee

review_title: Good benefits, poor support from leadership

job_title: PCT Patient Care Tech in Cedar Rapids, IA

job_title: Physical Therapist in Austin, TX

job_title: Graduate Student in Paso Robles, CA
pros: Everyone is so kind and welcoming. The community is close-knit and they truly care about the patients.

job_title: Wellness Coach in Cedar Rapids, IA
pros: The people are terrific and genuine.
cons: The pay is very poor and their are no career opportunities in my field.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Cedar Rapids, IA
pros: The front line workers are truly there to care for the patients.
cons: Management is horrible to everyone if you don’t “sit at their table”. They will lie to make themselves look good at the risk of damaging other’s careers. You will get in trouble if you ask too many questions. There is no one to turn to if you are having problems. You are better off not applying here... it will save you the headaches. They push good people out because they have different management skills that may not be as “hard” on employees as they like. Mercy touch is a joke when it comes to treating employees with respect. Some policies apply to some people, but not all people are held to the same standards if you are friends with someone in management. Mercy has a beautiful story, but greed and power are destroying it day by day. People in management walk around like others should bow to them; for the most part they are all crooked and corrupt people that think they are better to those around them. Sadly, they don’t seem that way until you’ve been there for awhile and you see what they do; don’t follow and be pushed out, or follow and be part of the problem.

review_title: Batch insurance and self pay payments/credit card payments for recon team and deposit into bank for daily depositing.
job_title: Payment Posting Representative in Cedar Rapids, IA
pros: Hours and dress code are great.
cons: Pay is terrible for the amount of work we are delegated.

job_title: Registered Nurse in Cedar Rapids, IA
pros: Most employees are pleasant and have good teamwork
cons: Not enough staff for patient caseload

job_title: Pct in Malden, MA
pros: I've met a ton of great people that I am friends with outside of work, often a lot of teamwork, people actually care about their patients. Those with more training will gladly teach new skills, and you can attend workshops for new training easily.
cons: With the dawn of EPIC (charting systems) there have been a lot of cutbacks - raises don't happen, good patient care supplies are switched for bad ones that are cheaper, etc. A lot of turnover - I don't know 90% of the floor I started on in the past two years! I really have a hard time stomaching the drama, as well as picking up the slack of dragging coworkers. A lot of your happiness will depend on the floor you work on. Also there have been shortages in staff. I've worked on floors with dangerously low staffing, I was actually uncomfortable with it. Oh and one reviewer said there's an onsite gym? Yeah we call that the fitness closet. Not a gym. A tiny room with a dual corner cable machine and some cardio equipment. It's not really a con but it is not a gym, sorry.

job_title: Patient Care Coordinator in Danvers, MA
pros: Amazing employees. Great atmosphere environment. Well cared facility
cons: None none none none none

review_title: Good place to work but a lot of challenges in the ED with contract doctors.
job_title: Care Coordination in Danvers, MA
pros: Mercy is not affiliated with any other Mercy hospital in Iowa so if you are unhappy you can't transfer to another hospital. Good place to work with fair but not great salaries. Salaries are competitive only to the CR area and does not include Iowa City. Great staff but ED doctors can be a challenge to work with. ED doctors don't listen to the advice or concerns of staff.
cons: ED doctors are contractors and are not employed through Mercy. This makes it a challenge for these providers to participate with the Mercy Touch and core values. They only care about their bottom line: their pay at the end of the day and to push as many patients through as possible to get their bonuses. Bonuses for ED providers are based on how many patients they push through to the ED. Very little time is spent on actual problem solving for patients and their families versus pushing them through to observation status or out the door. Nurse can be cliquey. Many staff use the ED as a stepping stone for experience out of school and then go to UIHC.

review_title: Great company; mediocre pay but competitive for hospitals in the area
job_title: Speech Language Pathologist in Cedar Rapids, IA
pros: Mercy Cedar Rapids is a strong and tight-knit company that has allowed me to meet lots of kind people. I have a fantastic direct supervisor and I work in a team that embraces flexibility and always has my back. There is an educational stipend and lots of encouragement to expand skills and grow your department. The benefits are good, overall. Additionally, the company made huge efforts to avoid layoffs during COVID-19 though did have mandatory hour cuts for a short period of time.
cons: For the therapy teams, productivity standards are constantly pushed and were increased about a month after I started which was annoying, but probably not unique to this hospital. Pay is low based on the national average though relatively competitive for nearby hospitals. Also, for insurance, you won't be covered for seeing a PCP that is not in the Mercycare network which was infuriating to me, personally, as I am local and have had the same doctor since I was born.

job_title: Staff Nurse in Cedar Rapids, IA
pros: The fellow staff that support each other in trying to keep the place going and provide top quality patient care.
cons:
Too many Indian chiefs at executive level with their own personal agendas. They are inexperienced and struggling. This deficit is well known in the community. Some should  stick to practicing in private practice and not be at that executive level. A level of intimidation and fear of repercussions amongst front line staff. There are large deficits in the HR dept and lacking effective leadership. Feel bad for CEO and CNO  
For they are left holding the bag and they are surrounded by amateurs in the executive roles.

job_title: Director of Clinic Operations in Cedar Rapids, IA
pros:
Competitive Compensation and Benefits
Serves a very important role in the community (charity care, concern for the poor, Hospice House)
Provides very good medical care with caring attitude
cons:
Limited opportunities for career advancement
Communication between management and staff was poor at times
Way too much money wasted on marketing.  
The seem to be an arms race between St. Luke's and Mercy.  Leadership is too concerned about who has what technology and wants to duplicate what the other has (robotic surgery, radiation therapy, etc) when there are better uses for their money.

job_title: BSN- RN Staff Nurse in Cedar Rapids, IA
pros: Benefits, health insurance is good. Coworkers can be great people. Free parking although there is walking usually involved across busy streets. Can be risky at night.
cons:
Pay, no pay increase for several years, basically if the administrators don't reach their profit "goal," they will not give pay increases except to management to meet their goals.
Management only cares about meeting their goals, can be cutthroat. 
You may work 4 hours one week and 70 the next. And thus you will not get overtime.
As a nurse you may work 630am until 2am the next morning without a break and be expected to be at work by 630 next morning. Management does not care about employee safety, only staffing the minimum requirements.

review_title: New motto: "The Mercy Touch" as long as it doesn't cost too much
job_title: Registered Nurse in Cedar Rapids, IA
pros: Because of high staff turnover and thus less staff, lots of opportunity to pick up extra hours.  Gift certificate for cafeteria/gift shop at Christmas and birthday.  Good nurse residency and orientation programs.  Can park closer to hospital (in ramp) at night and on weekends.  Get 8 hours of pay and $200 annually toward conferences/CEUs.  Good clinical ladder program.
cons:
- Parking if working day shift (its actually dangerous due to a run down neighborhood)
- Shift differential way too low (compared to the hospital up the street)
- High administrator turn over; current CEO was much more effective when in a secondary administrative position
- Focus is on money, not what is best for patient
- Benefits okay, but very low pay with no raises for 3 years (at least) despite being promised raises last summer (this was stopped the week before the raises were going to go into effect)
- Hospital is "Midas" happy - have to write each other up for even the smallest infractions rather than simply talking to each other
- Some units are extremely "clicky"
- We're getting burned out by working so much to be sure our patients (and staff) are safe

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Cedar Rapids, IA
pros: Above average benefits overall, and not surprisingly wonderful medical benefits. Does offer some leadership development opportunities.
cons: Just below market average on wages (benefits are great, but they just don't pay the rent), advancement opportunities can be pretty limited.

review_title: The nights team on pulmonary medicine center (MedSurg) are great at orienting new nurses.
job_title: Staff Nurse in Cedar Rapids, IA
pros: Certifications (ACLS, PALS, ETC) paid for out of an education fund in form of 8 hours. Lots of scholarships for ongoing ed. Pt ratios are good on overnights (4-6).  Great clinical ladder program and opportunities to be involved with committees of interest.
cons: Haven't increased starting wage for new nurses in two years for cost of living increases.  Need to work out some staffing links to ensure plenty of nurses and techs for all shifts and less mandating occurs.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Cedar Rapids, IA
pros: Good Benefits, Growing Hospital and Clinics.
cons: Mercy pays less. Work loads are heavy. Not a lot of flexibility.  Lack of growth for employees. Policies need revised. No personal time. Holidays are not paid, you must use your paid time off.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Cedar Rapids, IA
pros: Reasonable salaries, wages and benefits. Generous PTO, competitive pay, many optional benefits to take advantage of. Sometimes promoting from within is not the best for the organization.
cons: Executive management does not have patient's best interests at heart. It seems beating the competitor is more important than enhancing the excellent care certain departments offer.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Cedar Rapids, IA
pros: If you want to work for a hospital that delivers height quality care with compassion, Mercy is for you. Mercy staff cares for the sick and enhances the health of our community. I'd recommend the care and as a great place to work.
cons: All healthcare is being asked to do more with less. Mercy has its challenges, every place does, but we will come up with creative solutions. We are strong - we survived the flood of 2008.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Cedar Rapids, IA
pros: There are NO pros to working here.
cons: Pay is not great and can't even take vacation due to no help! Poor managers/supervisors; the worst I've seen!

job_title: Phlebotomist Technician in Cedar Rapids, IA
pros: You get to have multiple interactions with patients and areas of the hospital which is very exciting and rewarding. I got to work closely with nurses, doctors and other staff which was fun.
cons: You  had to be flexible in your schedule and it was mandatory to work holidays and weekends. The turn over rate can be a lot to handle because staff is consistently changing.

job_title: Patient Accounts in Cedar Rapids, IA
pros: None, you can work at home if you meet requirements, but don't hold your breath.
cons: Management is wishy washy. Has no firm policies in place. Each dept can make own policies as they go. Lots of drama, employees treat each other with disrespect over & over--no one ever does anything about it.

review_title: I finished my first year and know this is the place to settle down
job_title: Staff Nurse in Cedar Rapids, IA
pros: Good benefits. I love working with the people on my floor. The orientation was good and I really like my nurse manager
cons: need to add higher yearly repayment of tuition reimbursement. When I first came there was mandating they have hired additional PRNs to assist in taking extra shifts

job_title: Quality Systems Analyst in Cedar Rapids, IA
pros: Patient care is superior to the closes competitor for staff is embracing the ICARE values.
cons: Company's fiscal responsibilities often undervalues contributions employees bring to the table

job_title: Systems Analyst in Cedar Rapids, IA
pros: The best reason to work at Mercy is the ability to wear jeans to work.
cons: Challenges of working at Mercy in the e-services settings is the lack of compensation for hard work and dedication. Being with Mercy for many years, showing your dedication to a company and working hard to ensure end users are happy is not recognized. A previous employee was making at least $12,000 more walking in the door with no previous background in the same field. Dedication and hard work do not pay off here.

review_title: Wonderful place to work.    #1 in Patient Care!

job_title: in Cedar Rapids, IA
